TV Review: Hannibal Season 2 Episode 10: 'Naka-Choko'

03/05/2014

"This is my design." Adnan Riaz reviews

Image by

By James Bithell

Rating: 'Naka-Choko' is the latest achievement delivered from NBC's Hannibal and its experience from the opening moments to its concluding scene will have any viewer on the edge of their seat. Hannibal not only picks up the momentum in this episode but the preview for next week establishes that season two will continue to keep pushing the boundaries of the show. "This is my design." These are the words that have resonated from Will Graham (Hugh Dancy) over the course of two seasons, but now there is an exploration and transition of the character's personality (or so we think). Hannibal sends its farewell to Randall by having certain parts of his dismembered body planted onto the skeleton of an animal. As it has been said before, meeting your demise in Hannibal will never be a pleasant sight. Freddie Lounds (Lara Jean Chorostecki) re-emerges into the frame of this week's episode and has her crucial on-screen time for the season. 'Naka-Choko' allows the focus to be spread across multiple characters and offers one of, if not, the best Hannibal viewings to date. Will's proclamation to Freddie that he already has an ending with the Chesapeake Ripper in their conversation immediately changed the atmosphere of the episode, with it leaving an interesting thought to ponder on how the final three episodes will play out. Margot Verger (Katharine Isabelle) returns to her therapy session with Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Mads Mikkelsen) and, of course, there is nothing else on her agenda than killing her brother - with Hannibal spurring this motion forward. However, the highlight of this episode is the first appearance of Margot's brother, Mason Verger (Michael Pitt). The latest character from the Hannibal universe is only in the episode for approximately five minutes and he steals the episode every moment he can with his performance. Pitt's relationship with Isabelle and Mikkelsen can be described as nothing more than the finest acting that television has to offer. Mason's construction of a pig maze and his live demonstration of them being fed a dummy dressed in his sister's clothes is a truly chilling scene from 'Naka-Choko'. Pitt will no doubt have more to offer to the character's history in the final three episodes - which is something that everyone will be looking forward to. Hannibal's entire episode structure never leaves a moment which cannot be up for discussion, and this is the case with Margot paying her visit to the Graham residence once again. Margot and Will have an intimate session which is fused together with the sex scene that Hannibal and Alana have. Transition shots are significant in Hannibal and the scene not only adds to a crucial plot point for Margot's obsession of having an heir to her family's legacy, but also the similarities that Hannibal and Will are becoming one in the same. Freddie's journalistic actions were a sign from the beginning that they would come back to haunt the character. Her exploration of Will's shed and the discovery of Randall's suit and dismembered body parts in the freezer mimicked the moment that Beverley Katz had with Hannibal earlier in the season. However, Hannibal's plot always has a deeper meaning behind every action and, for that reason, it's easy to dismiss that Freddie is not dead - considering the scene before had Hannibal suited up and waiting to kill her. The final moments of the episode emphasise that 'Naka-Choko' could have easily been the season finale for Hannibal. Will's exploration of a personality that links with Hannibal Lecter has him adopt the latter's traits throughout the course of the entire episode. The final dinner scene between the two even has Will smelling his wine in Hannibal's unique manner. Furthermore, the final close-up of Will's face slowly fading into Lecter's reiterates the exceptional cinematography Hannibal continues to deliver. 'Naka-Choko' is without a doubt one of the best episodes that Hannibal has had to offer. Not only is it an episode which is exceptional in every aspect, but it sets up momentum for the final three episodes of season two. With the rumours currently circulating that Hannibal may be renewed for its third season, this episode is the perfect example as to why the show should have been renewed after the first few episodes from season two.
